newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: DUTCH TO USE CASH RESERVE TO REDUCE BORROWING.
newsitem.headline: DUTCH TO USE CASH RESERVE TO REDUCE BORROWING.

text.p: The Dutch state will use an obsolete cash reserve at the central bank to fund part of its 33.5 billion guilder 1997 borrowing requirement, the Finance Ministry said on Tuesday.

"The cash reserve will be used to cut the amount that the government will actually have to borrow and thereby contributes to a lower public debt as a percentage of gross domestic product," Finance Ministry spokesman Raymond Salet said.
Budget documents said the central government borrowing requirement, before the injection of cash reserves, would fall to 33.5 billion guilders in 1997 from 35.1 billion in 1996.
A well-informed source at the Finance Ministry said that roughly 10 billion guilders from the cash reserve would be used to reduce the borrowing requirement of 33.5 billion guilders.

The cash reserve was previously used to finance the short-term liquidity needs of the Dutch state, but is being phased out because of changes in monetary policy agreed within the framework of European Monetary Union (EMU).
"The cash reserve is gradually phased out and reduced to close to zero in 1997," Salet said.
The cash reserve is estimated at 11.2 billion guilders at the end of 1996, the Finance Ministry said.
